cards.front: What is the associated variable convention?
cards.back: Current is defined as positive when entering the positive voltage terminal. Under this convention, P = VI > 0 means the element absorbs power.

cards.front: What is the V-I relationship for an ideal wire?
cards.back: V = 0 for all I. Zero resistance, vertical line on V-I plot. Any current can flow without voltage drop.

cards.front: What is conductance G and its unit?
cards.back: G = 1/R, measured in siemens (S). It's the slope of the I-vs-V line. Useful for parallel combinations: G_total = G₁ + G₂ + G₃.

cards.front: What is the slope of a resistor's V-I characteristic?
cards.back: The slope is G = 1/R (conductance), NOT R. A steeper line means lower resistance and higher conductance. From I = GV, slope = ΔI/ΔV = G.

cards.front: What is the V-I characteristic of an ideal voltage source?
cards.back: A vertical line at V = E. The voltage is constant regardless of current. Direction of current doesn't matter — the source maintains fixed voltage.

cards.front: What is the V-I characteristic of an ideal current source?
cards.back: A horizontal line at I = I₀. The current is constant regardless of voltage. The voltage adjusts to satisfy the rest of the circuit.

cards.front: Write the terminal voltage equation for a battery with internal resistance.
cards.back: V = E − I·R_int (Thévenin model). E is the EMF, R_int is internal resistance. Terminal voltage drops linearly with current. V-I plot has negative slope −1/R_int.

cards.front: What is the short-circuit current of a battery?
cards.back: I_SC = E / R_int. Found by setting V = 0 in the Thévenin equation. This is the maximum current the battery can deliver (and is dangerous for real batteries).

cards.front: If P = VI is negative under the associated convention, what does it mean?
cards.back: The element is delivering power to the circuit (acting as a source), not absorbing it. Negative P means energy flows OUT of the element.

cards.front: How do you find the operating point of a battery connected to a load resistor?
cards.back: Plot both V-I lines on the same graph: battery line (V = E − IR_int) and load line (V = IR_L). The intersection is the operating point. This is the load-line method.

cards.front: Why is the V-I characteristic called a 'universal language' for circuit elements?
cards.back: Any two-terminal element — simple or complex, linear or nonlinear — is completely characterised by its V-I relationship. Analysis always reduces to finding where V-I curves intersect.

cards.front: State all three forms of the power equation for a resistor.
cards.back: P = VI = I²R = V²/R. All three are always positive because a resistor always absorbs power (converts to heat). They are equivalent via Ohm's law substitution.
